Title.evidence: Anterolateral Versus Midline Skin Incision in Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: 69 knees were assigned to TKA via either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they required TKA and were recruited from a single orthopedic center

Intervention.evidence: TKA via either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether an anterolateral skin incision reduces skin hypesthesia and postoperative discomfort

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area of skin hypesthesia, measured using Semmes-Weinstein monofilament at 13 reference points at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months postoperatively

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors

Result_Outcome.evidence: The anterolateral incision group exhibited significantly smaller areas of hypesthesia compared to the midline group at all time points: 32 cm² vs. 76 cm² at 6 weeks, 14 cm² vs. 29 cm² at 6 months, and 7 cm² vs. 19 cm² at 1 year
